class.name: BigNumber
class.brief_description: A high-performance Big Number class designed for idle, incremental, and strategy games requiring massive numbers.
class.description:
[BigNumber] is a [RefCounted] class designed to handle numbers efficiently that far exceed the limits of standard 64-bit integers and floating-point types.
Internally, it uses a mantissa and exponent representation (similar to scientific notation), allowing it to store and manipulate vastly large numbers while maintaining relevant precision.
It provides a robust suite of formatting methods to present these large numbers in user-friendly ways, including: - [b]Scientific notation:[/b] Standard scientific format (e.g., "1.23e15"). - [b]Metric symbols:[/b] SI prefixes like k, M, G, T, P, E (e.g., "1.5M"). - [b]Metric names:[/b] Full names like million, billion, trillion (e.g., "1.5 million"). - [b]AA notation:[/b] Alphabetical notation often used in mobile idle games (e.g., "aa", "ab", "ac").
Note: While this class manages extremely large numbers, it is a floating-point based "Big Number" implementation, not an arbitrary-precision integer library (like GMP). It trades absolute precision at the lowest decimal places for extreme range and performance, which is ideal for game mechanics.

method.name: absolute
method.description: Returns a new [BigNumber] containing the absolute value of this number (always positive).

method.name: divide
method.description: Divides the current number by [param n] and returns the result as a new [BigNumber]. [param n] can be a [BigNumber], [float], [int], or a scientific notation [String].

method.name: divide_equals
method.description: Divides the current number by [param n] in-place, modifying this object. Returns self to allow chaining.

method.name: floor_value
method.description: Rounds this number down to the nearest whole integer.

method.name: get_options
method.description:
Returns the global configuration dictionary used for text formatting. You can modify the values in this dictionary to globally change how numbers are formatted (e.g., the number of decimal places, separators, etc.).
Options include: - [code]scientific_decimals[/code]: Number of decimal places for scientific notation. - [code]thousand_separator[/code]: Character used for thousands (e.g., ","). - [code]decimal_separator[/code]: Character used for decimals (e.g., "."). - [code]small_decimals[/code], [code]thousand_decimals[/code], [code]big_decimals[/code]: Precision settings for different ranges in prefix formatting.

method.name: is_equal_to
method.description: Returns [code]true[/code] if this number is numerically approximate to [param n].

method.name: is_greater_than
method.description: Returns [code]true[/code] if this number is strictly greater than [param n].

method.name: is_greater_than_or_equal_to
method.description: Returns [code]true[/code] if this number is greater than or equal to [param n].

method.name: is_less_than
method.description: Returns [code]true[/code] if this number is strictly less than [param n].

method.name: is_less_than_or_equal_to
method.description: Returns [code]true[/code] if this number is less than or equal to [param n].

method.name: ln
method.description: Calculates the natural logarithm (base [i]e[/i]) of the number. Useful for logarithmic formulas often found in game balancing.

method.name: log10
method.description: Calculates the base-10 logarithm of the number. This is very fast and useful for determining orders of magnitude.

method.name: minus
method.description: Subtracts [param n] from the current number and returns the result as a new [BigNumber].

method.name: minus_equals
method.description: Subtracts [param n] from the current number in-place, modifying this object. Returns self.

method.name: mod
method.description: Calculates the modulo (remainder) of this number divided by [param n].

method.name: multiply
method.description: Multiplies the current number by [param n] and returns the result as a new [BigNumber].

method.name: multiply_equals
method.description: Multiplies the current number by [param n] in-place, modifying this object. Returns self.

method.name: normalize
method.description: Canonicalizes the internal representation so that the mantissa is between [code]1.0[/code] (inclusive) and [code]10.0[/code] (exclusive). This is called automatically after most operations, but can be called manually if you modify properties directly.

method.name: plus
method.description: Adds [param n] to the current number and returns the result as a new [BigNumber].

method.name: plus_equals
method.description: Adds [param n] to the current number in-place, modifying this object. Returns self to allow chaining.

method.name: power
method.description: Raises this number to the power of [param n] (exponentiation) and returns a new [BigNumber].

method.name: power_equals
method.description: Raises this number to the power of [param n] in-place.

method.name: square_root
method.description: Returns a new [BigNumber] representing the square root of this number.

method.name: to_aa
method.description: Formats the number using generic alphabetic notation (e.g., 1.23aa, 4.50ab), which is popular in many idle games for endless progression. - [param no_decimals_on_small_values]: If true, small numbers (under 1000) will be integers. - [param use_thousand_symbol]: If true, uses 'k' for thousands before switching to 'aa'.

method.name: to_float
method.description: Converts the number to a standard GDScript [float]. [b]Warning:[/b] Standard floats have a maximum value of roughly [code]1.79e308[/code]. If this BigNumber exceeds that, the result will be [code]INF[/code].

method.name: to_metric_name
method.description: Formats the number using full metric names (e.g., 1.50 million, 2.45 billion). If the number exceeds the defined metric prefixes, it falls back to scientific notation.

method.name: to_metric_symbol
method.description: Formats the number using standard International System of Units (SI) symbol suffixes (e.g., 1.50 M, 2.45 G). Supported array: k, M, G, T, P, E, Z, Y, R, Q. Falls back to scientific notation for larger values.

method.name: to_plain_scientific
method.description: Returns a raw string representation in scientific format without extra formatting rules (e.g., "1.2345e50"). Useful for serialization or debugging.

method.name: to_prefix
method.description: Formats the number using the "Engineering" style, where exponents are multiples of 3. This is the base helper for other formatting methods but can be used directly for custom display logic. - [param force_decimals]: Ensures a fixed number of decimal places are shown.

method.name: to_scientific
method.description: Formats the number in formatted scientific notation (e.g., "1.23e15"). Respects global options for decimal places and separators.

members.member: The exponent part of the number. The value is [code]mantissa * 10^exponent[/code].
The mantissa (significand) part of the number. When normalized, this is a value [code]>= 1.0[/code] and [code]< 10.0[/code].
